awd_titl_txt: AMS Community Synthesis for Convergence of Health and the Geosciences
awd_abstract_narration:
Due to climate change and the increasing concentration of human beings, human health is becoming increasing impacted by environmental changes such as extreme heat and cold snaps, flooding, wildfires, the northward migration of tropical insect-borne diseases, the urban heat island effect, the increasing occurrence of harmful algal blooms, and environmental degradation due to release and/or burial of anthropogenically-generated pollutants originating from waste, manufacturing, and mining. Many of the above phenomena, whether related to climate change or the impact of people on the natural environment, especially those related to atmospheric transport and other air-borne physical and chemical processes, have imposed significant and serious impacts on human health. These impacts are being felt not only in the US, but worldwide. To inform the public of these risks and explore the feasibility of possible solutions, the American Meteorological Society (AMS), a professional society of 13,000 atmospheric scientists; companies; and enthusiasts, will carry out an information gathering activity to collect input from its constituents on issues in climate and atmospheric processes that have impacts on human health and that are primed to be quickly addressed/resolved. A report, summarizing the outcome of this survey, will be generated and made available to the public via publication on the American Meteorological Society website and presented to the National Science Foundation Directorate of Geosciences. Key outcomes will be the identification of atmospheric changes and processes with the highest human-health impacts resulting from pollution and climate change that are primed for immediate resolution and/or intervention. Broader Impacts of the activity will a focus on improving our understanding and mitigation of atmospherically related environmental changes on human health.  
 
The American Meteorological Society (AMS) will conduct a broad, inclusive, results-driven survey of its constituents which consist of scientists and students as well as industry professionals in the atmospheric sciences and weather/climate prediction. This information collection exercise will gather ideas and target areas where geoscientists, communities, toxicologists, and medical professionals can come together to accelerate our nation's ability to mitigate and minimize human health impacts of changes in our environment due to climate and anthropogenic activities. Results of the survey will be summarized to provide a roadmap for the creation of potential workable solutions to help ameliorate the impacts of the environment on human health and society. In the final report targets will be identified that can be addressed in a significant way within a 2 to 3-year timeframe. Information gathering will include online survey vehicles, virtual gatherings, one-on-one discussions with experts, and broad outreach across the atmospheric sciences. An important aspect of the survey effort will be engagement of early career scientists and members of groups historically underrepresented in the sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project solicited and synthesized input from the American Meteorological Society (AMS) community on the connections, gaps, and opportunities at the interface of health, geoscience, and the Earth system (a.k.a. geohealth). The study was conducted on an accelerated time frame: over the course of approximately eight weeks, AMS Policy Program staff reached out to the network of scientists and practitioners within the AMS community for one-on-one conversations and small group discussions. Input from the full membership was also encouraged via a dedicated web portal and various media channels. The process promoted discussion within and across disciplines (health and natural sciences, geosciences, and social sciences) and organizations (public, private, academic, and NGO). Particular attention was dedicated towards identifying areas of convergence with the potential for significant impact in the short-term (e.g., over the next 2-3 years) that might also have positive impacts on both scientific advancement and societal applications of science over a much longer period.

These efforts resulted in a synthesis report, freely available on the AMS Policy Program website. The report identified three overarching challenges that currently form barriers to progress in geohealth research, five specific research areas which surveyed community members considered to be of particularly high impact, and five overarching throughlines to help enable a culture of innovation, entrepreneurialism, and translational research at the geohealth interface?as well as a more inclusive, equitable, and scientific enterprise as a whole. These issues are expanded upon in the report and recommendations for NSF, and the broader scientific enterprise, are provided.

The findings of the report were presented in conjunction with the findings of two other professional scientific societies, the American Geophysical Union (AGU) and Geological Society of America (GSA), at a town hall at each society?s annual meeting (GSA in October 2022, AGU in December 2022, AMS in January 2023). These town hall presentations helped to spread awareness of the opportunities and challenges at the geohealth interface within and beyond each society?s community and promoted intersectional partnership to continue advancing knowledge relating to this crucial field.
